newsitem.title: SLOVENIA: Slovenian shares down as profit-taking continues.
newsitem.headline: Slovenian shares down as profit-taking continues.

text.p: Slovenian shares fell on Monday as investors continued to take profits out of a recent bull run, but market participants said the potential for further declines was limited.
"Currently the feeling on the market is a little nervous, but I think shares fell enough and a rebound could come very soon," one broker said.
The SBI index fell 18.72 points or 1.44 percent to 1,249.9. Overall 13 shares fell, five rose and one was unchanged, while five issues were untraded.
Bank SKB was the most actively traded share, falling 1.69 percent to close at 40,020 tolars on volume of 1,450 shares for total turnover of 184.4 million tolars.
"SKB fell today after making big advances recently on rumours that it will list its shares in London," said Iztok Slapar, a trader at brokerage Nika. SKB has declined to comment on the issue.
Trading company Kovinotehna was the leading decliner, falling 5.99 percent to 455 tolars on volume of 2,666 shares.
Drug maker Lek's issue "C" was the biggest gainer, firming 2.94 percent to 21,000 tolars on volume of two shares. Lek's "A" issue rose 2.23 percent to 21,980 tolars on volume of 7,069 shares.
Total turnover fell to 399.3 million tolars from 461.6 million tolars on Friday.
